docs.lead_paragraph: As Democrats prepared for the president to sign their landmark legislation, Republicans opened a campaign to repeal it and use it as a weapon in midterm elections.

headline.main: Health Vote Is Done, but Partisan Debate Rages On
headline.sub: President to Sign Landmark Overhaul Bill on Tuesday
headline.print_headline: Health Vote Is Done, but Partisan Debate Rages On

docs.snippet: As Democrats prepared for the president to sign their landmark legislation, Republicans opened a campaign to repeal it and use it as a weapon in midterm elections.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN  and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: The president plans to open a campaign to persuade skeptical Americans, while Republicans talk of repeal.

headline.print_headline: Legal and Political Fights Are Looming for Democrats

docs.snippet: The president plans to open a campaign to persuade skeptical Americans, while Republicans talk of repeal.

byline.original: By JEFF ZELENY and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: The landmark health care overhaul passed by the House will provide medical coverage to tens of millions of uninsured Americans and will have an impact on nearly everyone who already has insurance. Readers, understandably, have questions about it all. On Monday, Ron Lieber, Tara Siegel Bernard, Jennifer Saranow Schultz and Natasha Singer of The New York Times answered readers' queries online. Here are edited versions of the questions and answers:

headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Excerpts of readers' questions and responses from Times reporters about landmark health care legislation; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The landmark health care overhaul passed by the House will provide medical coverage to tens of millions of uninsured Americans and will have an impact on nearly everyone who already has insurance. Readers, understandably, have questions about it all....

docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier today, The Agenda answered a question from a small-business owner about how the new health care law - which President Obama will sign Tuesday - might affect his future. That answer, in turn, begat more reader questions (like this comment about the small-business tax credit). The new law is big and complex, and we suspect there are many more questions out there. So if you own a small business, or work for one, we invite your questions about health insurance coverage and the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Send Us Your Small-Business Health Reform Questions

docs.abstract: Wondering how the new law will affect your business? We'll try to sort it out for you.
docs.snippet: Wondering how the new law will affect your business? We'll try to sort it out for you.

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the big reasons House Democrats wanted changes to the Senate-passed health care bill was the so-called Cornhusker kickback, which provided extra Medicaid money for Nebraska.

headline.main: Nelson to Vote Against Reconciliation Bill

docs.abstract: The senator at the heart of the controversy over the "Cornhusker kickback" said he will vote against the reconciliation bill passed by the House.
docs.snippet: The senator at the heart of the controversy over the "Cornhusker kickback" said he will vote against the reconciliation bill passed by the House.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said on Monday that he would propose legislation requiring  President Obama and White House officials obtain their health insurance through the government exchanges that will be established under the health care bill Mr. Obama is planning to sign on Tuesday.

headline.main: Grassley Wants Obama to Enroll in New Exchanges

docs.abstract: Senator Charles E. Grassley will propose legislation requiring that the president and White House staffers purchase their insurance through the new national health exchanges.
docs.snippet: Senator Charles E. Grassley will propose legislation requiring that the president and White House staffers purchase their insurance through the new national health exchanges.

docs.lead_paragraph: After the House approved landmark health care legislation on Sunday, President Obama said the passage is "a victory for the American people. And it's a victory for common sense. " (Video: MSNBC)

headline.main: MSNBC: Obama's Remarks After the Bill
headline.sub: Health Bill Is 'a Victory for the American People'

docs.snippet: After the House approved landmark health care legislation on Sunday, President Obama said the passage is "a victory for the American people. And it's a victory for common sense. " (Video: MSNBC)

docs.lead_paragraph: Assuming that repeal isn't an option, the best-case scenario for conservatives is suggested by a point James Capretta made last week, analyzing the latest draft of the legislation.
docs.abstract: A look at what might happen next.
docs.snippet: A look at what might happen next.

docs.lead_paragraph: When is a child grown and on his or her own?

headline.main: When Adult Children Move Back Home

docs.abstract: What are the rules when an adult child returns home?
docs.snippet: What are the rules when an adult child returns home?

docs.lead_paragraph: Unlike some of his peers, Morgan Stanley's chairman, John J. Mack, has been vocal in his support of financial regulatory reform, something he still calls for. But he told Fox Business Network on Monday that it's going to be a little harder to pass in the wake of the rancorous health care overhaul debate.

headline.main: Mack: We Still Need Financial Regulatory Reform

docs.abstract: John J. Mack, the chairman of Morgan Stanley, told Fox Business Network that Wall Street still needs needs new regulation, though that might be a little tougher to accomplish in the wake of the rancorous health care debate.
docs.snippet: John J. Mack, the chairman of Morgan Stanley, told Fox Business Network that Wall Street still needs needs new regulation, though that might be a little tougher to accomplish in the wake of the rancorous health care debate.
